sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: &app; is a Gnome2 frontend for Gnu Privacy Guard. &app; provides the following components:

&app; is an application and a project. The primary goal of the &app; application is to provide an easy to use yet powerful key manager tool. The secondary goal is to provide basic encryption capabilities. The goal of the project is to provide the &app; application, along with plugins for Gnome applications to make encryption easy on the Gnome Desktop.

sect2.title: To Start &app;
sect2.para: You can start &app; in the following ways:

sect2.title: When You Start &app;
sect2.para: When you start &app;, the Key Manager is displayed.
The Key Manager window contains the following elements:

listitem.para: The menubar contains commands for accessing the various dialogs and windows.
The toolbar only contains commands that affect keys.

The key list shows the keys in your key ring. Some keys also have sub keys. Each key and sub key show the following attributes:
Name
Key ID
Trust
Type
Length
Only one key may be selected at a time.
The statusbar shows operation status messages. Operations are either successful or fail.

sect1.title: Usage
sect1.para: You can use the &app; application to access the following features:
Any window with a menubar contains a View menu. In the View menu, you may choose whether or not to view the Toolbar or Statusbar. Selecting either option will hide or show the selected component.
Any window with a statusbar will display status messages from operations. The current or last focused statusbar can also display operation progress.
You can get help for a feature by clicking help in a dialog or selecting Help.
sect1.warning: While &app; is in use, do not make any changes to the key ring with another program. External changes could have unkown and possibly undesirable affects.

sect2.title: Generating a Key
sect2.para: To generate a new key, choose FileNew from the Key Manager. The Generate Key dialog is displayed. You will need to enter your full name, a valid email address, and a comment describing the key. This will create the primary user ID. You will then need to choose a key type and a key length. The range of the length depends on the type selected. Then you must choose a key expiration date, or have the key never expire. When finished, click OK.
sect2.warning: No other operations should be performed during key generation. Doing so will stop the generation process prematurely.

sect2.title: Importing Keys
sect2.para:
To import keys, choose FileOpen... from the Key Manager. The Import Keys dialog is displayed.
Import from a file
To import keys from a file, select Import from File, choose a file, then click OK.
Import from text
To import keys from text, select Import from Text, paste the text into the text area, then click OK. The text must be ascii armored in order to be imported successfully.

sect2.title: Exporting a Key
sect2.para:
To export a key from the Key Manager, select a key from the list and then choose FileSave As... or click Save As. You can do the same from the of the key you want to export. The Export Key dialog is displayed.
Export to File
To export a key to a file, select Export to File, choose the filename, then click OK.
Export to Text
To export a key to text, select Export to Text, then click OK. The exported key will be in the text area. If is not enabled, exported text will not display properly.

sect2.title: Text Editor
sect2.para:
To use the text editor, choose FileText Editor from the Key Manager. should be enabled while using the Text Editor. Otherwise, text will not be displayed properly, rendering the Text Editor useless. The following operations are available for text:
Import
Select EditImport, click Import, or right-click and select Import. This will import any keys contained in the text.
Export
Select EditExport. The dialog will appear, in which you can select keys to export. When finished, the chosen keys will be exported to the text.
Sign
Select EditSign, click Sign, or right-click and select Sign. After confirming the to the , the text will be signed.
Clear Sign
Select EditClear Sign, click Clear Sign, or right-click and select Clear Sign. After confirming the to the , the text will be clear signed.
Encrypt
Select EditEncrypt, click Encrypt, or right-click and select Encrypt. The dialog will appear, in which you can select the keys to encrypt to. When finished, the text will be encrypted to the selected keys.
Decrypt
You must have access to the secret key of one of the encryption keys in your key ring in order to decrypt the text.
Select EditDecrypt, click Decrypt, or right-click and select Decrypt and enter the . If successful, the text will be decrypted.
Verify
You must have the signing key in your key ring in order to successfully verify a signature.
Select EditVerify, click Verify, or right-click and select Verify. If successful, the dialog will appear. Otherwise, you will receive an error regarding how verification failed.
Decrypt and Verify
Decrypt and Verify combines the decrypt and verify operations by decrypting, then verifying the text. To decrypt and verify, select EditDecrypt and Verify or right-click and select Decrypt and Verify.

sect2.title: File Manager
sect2.para:
To use the File Manager, choose FileFile Manager from the Key Manager. The following operations are available for files:
Import
Choose an existing file, then select EditImport, or click Import. Any keys in the file will be added to the key ring.
Export
Enter a filename (the file does not have to exist), then select EditExport. The dialog will appear, in which you can select the keys to export. When finished, the exported keys will be appended to the file.
Sign
Choose an existing file to sign, then select EditSign, or click Sign. After confirming the to the , a detached signature file will be created with the same file name, but with a .asc or .sig extension, depending on whether is enabled.
Encrypt
Choose an existing file to encrypt, then select EditEncrypt, or click Encrypt. The dialog will appear, in which you can select the keys to encrypt to. When finished, a new, encrypted, file will be created with the same name, but with a .asc or .gpg extension, depending on whether is enabled.
Decrypt
You must have access to the secret key of one of the encryption keys in your key ring in order to decrypt a file.
Choose an encrypted file to decrypt. The filename must have a .asc or .gpg extension. After choosing the file, select EditDecrypt, or click Decrypt and enter the . If successful, a decrypted file will be created with the same name, but without the extension.
Verify
You must have the signing key in your key ring in order to successfully verify a signature.
Choose a detached signature file to verify. The signature file must have a .asc or .sig extension, and it must have the same name as the signed file, but without the extension.
Choosing a Detached Signature File
Select foo.sig or foo.asc, where the signed file foo is in the same directory.
After choosing the file, select EditVerify, or click Verify. If success, the dialog will appear, otherwise you will get an error message regarding how verification failed.
Decrypt and Verify
Decrypt and verify combines the decrypt and verify operations by decrypting the file, then verifying and signatures found. To decrypt and verify, choose an encrypted file then select EditDecrypt and Verify.

sect2.title: Key Properties
sect2.para: To view key properties, select a key from the list and choose EditProperties, click Properties, or double-click the key. The Key Properties window is displayed. From the Key Properties window, you can also access and .
The first attribute shown is the fingerprint. Below the fingerprint is the and . Next is the primary , list, and sub key list with .

sect3.title: Owner Trust
sect3.para: Use the option menu to change the owner trust of the key.

sect3.title: Disable Key
sect3.para: Checking Disable will disable the key. Most keys should be left enabled.

sect3.title: Key Attributes
sect3.para:
Both primary keys and sub keys have the following attributes:
Key ID
Algorithm
Creation date
Length

sect3.title: Key Expiration
sect3.para: If the key has a secret key, the expiration is shown as a date editor and a Never Expires checkbox. These can be used to change the key's expiration. Otherwise, the date is simply a label stating Never or the exact date.

sect3.title: User IDs
sect3.para: Below the is the list of user IDs.

sect3.title: Sub Keys
sect3.para: Below the list is the list of sub keys. Not all keys have sub keys. Sub keys have .

sect3.title: Change Passphrase
sect3.para: If the key has a secret key, you can select EditChange Passphrase. The first entry is for the original passphrase, the second entry is for the new passphrase.

sect2.title: Deleting a Key
sect2.para: To delete a key, choose EditDelete from the Key Manager, or click Delete. You can do the same from the window of the key that you want to delete. The Delete Key dialog is displayed. Click Yes to delete the key.
sect2.warning: This will permanently delete the key and cannot be undone.

sect2.title: Passphrase
sect2.para: This dialog is displayed when a passphrase must be entered, usually to unlock a secret key. The key for which the passphrase is needed is shown above the entry.

sect2.title: Signatures
sect2.para:
This dialog shows information about a verified signature.
Status
The status of the signature, usually Good.
Created
Creation date of the signature.
Signer
User ID of the signing key.
Key ID
Key ID of the signing key.

sect2.title: Recipients
sect2.para:
Use this dialog to select multiple recipients. Currently this used for exporting keys and encrypting data. The following information is shown for each key:
Name
Key ID
Validity
sect2.caution: Encryption requires that keys are at least Fully Valid.

sect1.title: Settings
sect1.para: To show the preferences, choose SettingsPreferences from any window with a menubar. The Preferences dialog is displayed.

sect2.title: Ascii Armor
sect2.para: Checking Ascii Armor will ensure that data is encoded as ASCII text instead of binary. This is necessary for the and part of functionality.

sect2.title: Text Mode
sect2.para: Checking Text Mode will enable text mode.

sect2.title: Default Signing Key
sect2.para: This option menu allows you to choose the default signing key for sign operations. The only keys shown are those that have a secret key and can sign.
